001package imagingbook.lib.filter.linear;
002
003import imagingbook.lib.filter.GenericFilter;
004import imagingbook.lib.filter.GenericFilterScalarSeparable;
005import imagingbook.lib.image.data.PixelPack.PixelSlice;
006
007/**
008 * This class represents a 2D linear filter that is x/y-separable and
009 * specified by two 1D-kernels.
010 * It is based on {@link GenericFilter} and {@link GenericFilterScalarSeparable},
011 * which take care of all data copying and filter mechanics.
012 * Since it is a "scalar" filter, pixel values are treated as scalars.
013 * If the processed image has more than one component 
014 * (e.g., a RGB color image), this filter is automatically 
015 * and independently applied to all (scalar-valued) components.
016 * To apply to an image, use the {@link #applyTo(ij.process.ImageProcessor)}
017 * method, for example.
018 */
019public class LinearFilterSeparable extends GenericFilterScalarSeparable {
020
021        private float[] hX = null;                      // the horizontal kernel array
022        private float[] hY = null;                      // the vertical kernel array
023        private int width = 0;                          // width of the effective kernel
024        private int height = 0;                         // height of the effective kernel
025        private int xc = 0;                                             // 'hot spot' x-position
026        private int yc = 0;                                             // 'hot spot' y-position
027        
028        /**
029         * Constructor, takes a 1D convolution kernel to be applied both
030         * in x- and y-direction. 
031         * 
032         * @param kernelXY a 1D convolution kernel
033         */
034        public LinearFilterSeparable(Kernel1D kernelXY) {
035                this(kernelXY, kernelXY);
036        }
037        
038        /**
039         * Constructor, takes two 1D convolution kernels to be applied
040         * in x- and y-direction, respectively.
041         * One (but not both) of the supplied kernels may be {@code null}.
042         * If this is the case, filtering in the associated direction
043         * is skipped.
044         * 
045         * @param kernelX a 1D kernel for convolution in x-direction
046         * @param kernelY a 1D kernel for convolution in y-direction
047         */
048        public LinearFilterSeparable(Kernel1D kernelX, Kernel1D kernelY) {
049                super();
050                
051                if (kernelX == null && kernelY == null) {
052                        throw new RuntimeException("both X/Y kernels may not be null");
053                }
054                
055                if (kernelX == null) {
056                        this.doX = false;       // skip X-part
057                }
058                else {
059                        this.hX = kernelX.getH();
060                        this.width = kernelX.getWidth();
061                        this.xc = kernelX.getXc();
062                }
063                
064                if (kernelY == null) {
065                        this.doY = false;       // skip Y-part
066                }
067                else {
068                        this.hY = kernelY.getH();
069                        this.height = kernelY.getWidth();
070                        this.yc = kernelY.getXc();
071                }
072        }
073
074        // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
075
076        // 1D convolution in x-direction
077        @Override
078        protected float doPixelX(PixelSlice source, int u, final int v) {
079                double sum = 0;
080                for (int i = 0; i < width; i++) {
081                        int ui = u + i - xc;
082                        sum = sum + source.getVal(ui, v) * hX[i];
083                }
084                return (float)sum;
085        }
086        
087        // 1D convolution in y-direction
088        @Override
089        protected float doPixelY(PixelSlice source, final int u, int v) {
090                double sum = 0;
091                for (int j = 0; j < height; j++) {
092                        int vj = v + j - yc;
093                        sum = sum + source.getVal(u, vj) * hY[j];
094                }
095                return (float)sum;
096        }
097
098}
